18.20: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because although the Destructions of the two Temples were caused by our corruption, we ourselves were spared;
18.21: and ours is the shamefacedness because we should have repented to You wholeheartedly so that You would return to us in compassion.
18.22: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because of the (almost) nine centuries throughout which You withheld Your anger (over our sins) and didn't broadcast it;
18.23: and ours is the shamefacedness because (Daniel) the man of delights pleaded with You (to end the Babylonian Exile after a mere seventy years, even though we were not worthy,) saying, 'Incline Your ear, O my God, and hear!'
18.1: and ours is the shamefacedness, because of the trial with which You sought to refine us, (but as a result of our failure) You despised us.
18.0: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness, because of the wondrous signs You have displayed from then until now;
18.3: and ours is the shamefacedness, because of the hypocrisy to be found within us as we emulated (Egypt's abominable) deeds.
18.2: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because You have taken (our) nation from amidst another nation, with miracles;
18.5: and ours is the shamefacedness, because they (our forefathers) rebelled on the shore of the Sea of reeds, the nation sinning against its God!
18.4: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because God went out to redeem us as a people unto Himself;
18.7: and, ours is the shamefacedness, because we blasphemed Hashem in (the Wilderness of) Sin (when we demanded of Aaron), 'Arise and create a god for us!'
18.6: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness when we recall the proclamation, 'You are witnesses, and I am God!'
18.9: and ours, is the shamefacedness, because on the day (we made the Golden Calf), we brought it an offering of fine flour with oil and honey.
18.8: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because You fed us (the manna) that tasted like dough fried in honey;
18.11: and ours is the shamefacedness because our forefathers grumbled in their tents about (the manna and called it) the destructive bread.
18.10: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because you provided us with the manna, the well and the pillar of clouds;
18.13: and ours is the shamefacedness because we defied You as Laban, Hazeroth, and Di-zahab as related (by Moses),
18.12: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because in the wilderness we lacked for nothing;
18.15: and ours is the shamefacedness because of Achan who appropriated for himself from the forbidden spoils (of Jericho) and found no excuse (for his crime).
18.14: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because of (how You waged war for us with) Sihon and Og and all the kings of Canaan;
18.17: and ours is the shamefacedness because of Micah's idol through which we transgressed.
18.16: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because of all that You accomplished through the fourteen saviors(-Judges);
18.19: and ours is the shamefacedness because the evil in our midst caused each one's destruction, and in their loss, we have been humiliated.
18.18: Yours, my Lord, is the righteousness because You erected (Tabernacles) at Shiloh, Nob, Gibeon and the Eternal Temple (in Jerusalem);

44.20: And scream for the excitement of her cursers from within her sacred courts.
44.21: Scream for Your name that was desecrated by her besiegers.
44.22: And scream for the prayers that they will shout: Heed and listen to her words.
44.23: Scream for Zion and her cities like a woman giving birth, and like a bride dressed in mourning for her husband on her wedding night.
44.1: Scream for the castle abandoned, by fault of the sheep who make up her flock.
44.0: Scream for Zion and her cities like a woman giving birth, and like a bride dressed in mourning for her husband on her wedding night.
44.3: Scream for God’s exiled servants, who beautifully sang her melodies.
44.2: And scream for God’s despisers, who violated the sanctity of her chambers.
44.5: Scream for the tittering of her dancers, whose silence now fills her cities.
44.4: And scream for their blood, spilled like water through her canals.
44.7: Scream for her constant sacrifices and her redeemed first born.
44.6: And scream for the desolate assemblies, and for her Sanhedrin that no longer exists....
44.9: Scream for her princes, her noble Children of David.
44.8: And scream for the desecrated palace vessels, and the altar for her incense.
44.11: Scream for the dignity that vanished when they destroyed her shrines.
44.10: And scream for their beauty, extinguished the moment they removed her crowns.
44.13: Scream for the torment and the blows that her monks suffered.
44.12: And scream for the oppressor who replaced her dresses with sacks.
44.15: Scream for the joy of her haters as they laughed at her wounds.
44.14: And scream for her babies, their skulls cracked open upon the rocks.
44.17: Scream for the crimes that she committed as she paved the way for her iniquity.
44.16: And scream for the torture of her pure and noble citizens.
44.19: Scream for the cheers of her despisers as her corpses multiplied.
44.18: And scream for her myriad burned and blackened communities.

16.10: If one could ask of another: "Give over your son to eat" but he's already hidden, sliced into slices...
16.12: If fathers, now meat, could be seasoned for their sons in caves and trenches...
16.14: If daughters could be dandled in the breasts of their mothers, distended bellies...
16.16: If the ghosts of children, bloated with rot, floated in the streets of the city...
16.0: If women could eat the fruit of their womb, the little babes clapping their hands...
16.2: If women so full of compassion could boil their children, measured hand height by hand height...
16.4: If the fine locks of their heads could be shorn and bound as decorations for horses...
16.6: If the tongue of a nursing baby could glue to his palate from blinding white thirst...
16.8: If one could sigh one to another: "Come on and let's boil our screeching sons...
